evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is supported by multiple sources and evidence in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal case, making alternative explanations less plausible.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal incident.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against common defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal context, ensuring reliable detection.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal scope, reflecting typical operational variances.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: The observed lack of warnings and assumptions by crew members indicate communication breakdown
No contradictory evidence exists in the packet to refute communication/coordination failure
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were the primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 document lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during the pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviation or communication breakdown was primary cause

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal dataset.

defeaters: If the dataset did not include explicit documentation of the procedural deviation or if evidence showed the event was due to communication breakdown rather than procedural deviation.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple history items (H1-H4, H8, H9, H11, H12) document the procedural deviation in pushback execution and its circumstances, supporting availability of this deviation in the dataset. The discriminator disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN is favored by evidence showing stop-point and continuation behavior under aligned crew model.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence directly documents the procedural deviation and its context.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal incident.

assumptions: The communication failures described are representative of crew resource management failures
No mechanical failures contributed significantly to the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviations without communication issues
If mechanical faults were confirmed causing the incident
If environmental or marking deficiencies were the primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 describe communication and coordination failures among crew members, including lack of warnings and assumptions, supporting the claim that the breakdown aligns with human factors and crew resource management failures.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or environmental factors contributed more

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal scope, reflecting typical operational variances.

assumptions: The TRP markings were visible and understood by operators as per training.
No mechanical or communication failures prevented proper pushback execution.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were unclear or missing, or if environmental factors prevented recognition of the TRP, this would favor environmental deficiency.
If equipment malfunction or control failure was documented, it would challenge the procedural deviation conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, H10, H12, and H13 show the pushback continued beyond the TRP despite visual markers and signals, indicating procedural deviation rather than environmental or marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in signal effectiveness and operator awareness; small TRP size noted but not deemed sufficient to explain deviation.

node.statement: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against common defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal context, ensuring reliable detection.

assumptions: No mechanical faults were detected or reported in the evidence.
The visual signals and communication methods described are representative of standard procedures.
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical control faults or bench checks indicating malfunction, this would challenge the procedural deviation identification.
If communication breakdown or environmental marking deficiencies were shown to cause the event, this would alter the conclusion.

assumptions: No mechanical fault was reported or detected in the evidence

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2, H8, and H12 indicate the pushback was controlled by the tug instructor and that no mechanical or control failure was reported; the continued movement past the TRP appears due to procedural or communication issues rather than mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct mechanical fault evidence; ambiguity whether slow continued movement was due to mechanical failure or procedural error

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is supported by multiple sources and evidence in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal case, making alternative explanations less plausible.

No significant unreported environmental or mechanical factors contributed to the incident.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and warnings were given and acknowledged among crew members.
If physical environment or marking deficiencies were proven to be the primary cause without crew miscommunication.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple sources (H8, H10, H12) describe communication lapses and assumptions among crew members, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown and making alternative explanations like marking deficiency less plausible.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in crew members' perceptions and assumptions about each other's actions; no explicit contradictory evidence.
